fields.name: Identification
fields.description: Terms relating to the taxonomic identification of a biological item.

fields.name: Taxon
fields.description: Terms relating to a biological item's taxonomy.

fields.name: Relationship
fields.description: Terms that indicate a relationship between entities in a collection.

fields.name: Dataset
fields.description: Data encoded in a defined structure.

fields.name: Locality
fields.description: Terms pertaining to the locality in which the item was collected or observed.

fields.name: Person
fields.description: Terms related to an agent or actor related to the collection, observation, identification or data processing of the records in the database.

fields.name: Notes
fields.description: Notes or descriptions terms of any kind, these may be attached to a variety of other terms of objects.

fields.name: Attribute
fields.description: Attribute terms are those that pertain specifically to the properties of the item being collected or observed. (E.g. length, weight)

fields.name: Archeology
fields.description: Attribute terms that are specific to archaeological or lithic characteristics.

fields.name: Biology
fields.description: Terms that specifically reference an item's biological attributes (E.g. taxon).

fields.name: Taphonomy
fields.description: Terms relating to the process of fossilization.

fields.name: Agent
fields.description: A resource that acts or has the power to act.

fields.name: PeriodOfTime
fields.description: An interval of time that is named or defined by its start and end dates.

fields.name: Image
fields.description: A visual representation other than text.

fields.name: PhysicalObject
fields.description: An inanimate, three-dimensional object or substance.

fields.name: Class
fields.description: A type or category of resource

fields.name: Multiple Categories
fields.description: A property of more than one class or category

fields.name: standard
fields.description: This term is a formally adopted field in a standardized schema.

fields.name: decimal
fields.description: A floating point number of any precision and length.

fields.name: unknown
fields.description: Field type is unknown at this time.

fields.definition: Data encoded in a defined structure.
fields.name: Dataset
fields.example: Examples include lists, tables, and databases. A dataset may be useful for direct machine processing.

fields.definition: A name given to the resource.
fields.name: title

fields.definition: An alternative name for the resource.
fields.name: alternative

fields.definition: The method by which items are added to a collection.
fields.name: accrualMethod

fields.definition: The frequency with which items are added to a collection.
fields.name: accrualPeriodicity

fields.definition: A class of entity for whom the resource is intended or useful.
fields.name: audience

fields.definition: Date (often a range) that the resource became or will become available.
fields.name: available

fields.definition: An established standard to which the described resource conforms.
fields.name: conformsTo

fields.definition: An entity responsible for making contributions to the resource.
fields.name: contributor

fields.definition: The spatial or temporal topic of the resource, the spatial applicability of the resource, or the jurisdiction under which the resource is relevant.
fields.name: coverage

fields.definition: Date of creation of the resource.
fields.name: created

fields.definition: An entity primarily responsible for making the resource.
fields.name: creator

fields.definition: An entity responsible for making the resource available.
fields.name: publisher

fields.definition: Examples of resources to which a Date Accepted may be relevant are a thesis (accepted by a university department) or an article (accepted by a journal).
fields.name: dateAccepted

fields.definition: Date of submission of the resource.
fields.name: dateSubmitted

fields.definition: The file format, physical medium, or dimensions of the resource.
fields.name: format

fields.definition: A class of entity, defined in terms of progression through an educational or training context, for which the described resource is intended.
fields.name: educationLevel

fields.definition:
A related resource that is substantially the same as the pre-existing described resource, but in another format.

This term is intended to be used with non-literal values as defined in the DCMI Abstract Model (http://dublincore.org/documents/abstract-model/). As of December 2007, the DCMI Usage Board is seeking a way to express this intention with a formal range declaration.
fields.name: hasFormat

fields.definition: A related resource that is included either physically or logically in the described resource.
fields.name: hasPart

fields.definition: A related resource that is a version, edition, or adaptation of the described resource.
fields.name: hasVersion

fields.definition: An unambiguous reference to the resource within a given context.
fields.name: identifier

fields.definition: A process, used to engender knowledge, attitudes and skills, that the described resource is designed to support.
fields.name: instructionalMethod

fields.definition: A related resource that is substantially the same as the described resource, but in another format.
fields.name: isFormatOf

fields.definition: A related resource in which the described resource is physically or logically included.
fields.name: isPartOf

fields.definition: A related resource that references, cites, or otherwise points to the described resource.
fields.name: isReferencedBy

fields.definition: A related resource that supplants, displaces, or supersedes the described resource.
fields.name: isReplacedBy

fields.definition: A related resource that requires the described resource to support its function, delivery, or coherence.
fields.name: isRequiredBy

fields.definition: Date of formal issuance (e.g., publication) of the resource.
fields.name: issued

fields.definition: A related resource of which the described resource is a version, edition, or adaptation.
fields.name: isVersionOf

fields.definition: A legal document giving official permission to do something with the resource.
fields.name: license

fields.definition: An entity that mediates access to the resource and for whom the resource is intended or useful.
fields.name: mediator

fields.definition: The material or physical carrier of the resource.
fields.name: medium

fields.definition: A statement of any changes in ownership and custody of the resource since its creation that are significant for its authenticity, integrity, and interpretation.
fields.name: provenance

fields.definition: A related resource that is supplanted, displaced, or superseded by the described resource.
fields.name: replaces

fields.definition: A related resource that is required by the described resource to support its function, delivery, or coherence.
fields.name: requires

fields.definition: A related resource from which the described resource is derived.
fields.name: source

fields.definition: Typically, the subject will be represented using keywords, key phrases, or classification codes. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: subject

fields.definition: A list of subunits of the resource.
fields.name: tableOfContents

fields.definition: Date on which the resource was changed.
fields.name: modified

fields.definition: The name identifying the data set from which the record was derived.
fields.name: datasetName
fields.example: Examples: "Grinnell Resurvey Mammals", "Lacey Ctenomys Recaptures". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:datasetName

fields.definition: An identifier for the set of data. May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to a collection or institution.
fields.name: datasetID
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:datasetID

fields.definition: Information about rights held in and over the resource.
fields.name: rights

fields.definition: A person or organization owning or managing rights over the resource.
fields.name: rightsHolder

fields.definition: Information about who can access the resource or an indication of its security status.
fields.name: accessRights

fields.definition: A bibliographic reference for the resource.
fields.name: bibliographicCitation

fields.definition: A related resource that is referenced, cited, or otherwise pointed to by the described resource.
fields.name: references

fields.definition: The nature or genre of the resource. PaleoCore uses its own type vocabulary.
fields.name: type
fields.example: archaeology, biology, geology

fields.definition: An identifier for the Occurrence (as opposed to a particular digital record of the occurrence). In the absence of a persistent global unique identifier, construct one from a combination of identifiers in the record that will most closely make the occurrenceID globally unique.
fields.name: occurrenceID
fields.example: For a specimen in the absence of a bona fide global unique identifier, for example, use the form: "urn:catalog:[institutionCode]:[collectionCode]:[catalogNumber]. Examples: "urn:lsid:nhm.ku.edu:Herps:32", "urn:catalog:FMNH:Mammal:145732". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:occurrenceID

fields.definition: Comments or notes about the Occurrence.
fields.name: occurrenceRemarks

fields.definition: An identifier given to the Occurrence at the time it was recorded. Often serves as a link between field notes and an Occurrence record, such as a specimen collector's number.
fields.name: recordNumber
fields.example: Example: "OPP 7101". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:recordNumber

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations responsible for recording the original Occurrence. The primary collector or observer, especially one who applies a personal identifier (recordNumber), should be listed first.
fields.name: recordedBy

fields.definition: The specific nature of the data record.
fields.name: basisOfRecord
fields.example: Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the list of Darwin Core classes. Examples: "PreservedSpecimen", "FossilSpecimen", "LivingSpecimen", "HumanObservation", "MachineObservation". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:basisOfRecord

fields.definition: An identifier for the institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
fields.name: institutionID
fields.example: For physical specimens, the recommended best practice is to use an identifier from a collections registry such as the Global Registry of Biodiversity Repositories (http://grbio.org/). Examples: "http://biocol.org/urn:lsid:biocol.org:col:34777", "http://grbio.org/cool/km06-gtbn). Examples: "http://biocol.org/urn:lsid:biocol.org:col:34777", "http://grbio.org/cool/km06-gtbn". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:institutionID

fields.definition: An identifier for the collection or dataset from which the record was derived.
fields.name: collectionID
fields.example: For physical specimens, the recommended best practice is to use an identifier from a collections registry such as the Global Registry of Biodiversity Repositories (http://grbio.org/). Examples: "http://biocol.org/urn:lsid:biocol.org:col:1001", "http://grbio.org/cool/p5fp-c036). Examples: "http://biocol.org/urn:lsid:biocol.org:col:1001", "http://grbio.org/cool/p5fp-c036". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:collectionID

fields.definition: The name (or acronym) in use by the institution having custody of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
fields.name: institutionCode
fields.example: Examples: "MVZ", "FMNH", "AKN-CLO", "University of California Museum of Paleontology (UCMP)". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:institutionCode

fields.definition: The name, acronym, coden, or initialism identifying the collection or data set from which the record was derived.
fields.name: collectionCode
fields.example: Examples: "Mammals", "Hildebrandt", "eBird". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:collectionCode

fields.definition: The name (or acronym) in use by the institution having ownership of the object(s) or information referred to in the record.
fields.name: ownerInstitutionCode
fields.example: Examples: "NPS", "APN", "InBio". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:ownerInstitutionCode

fields.definition: Additional information that exists, but that has not been shared in the given record.
fields.name: informationWithheld
fields.example: Examples: "location information not given for endangered species", "collector identities withheld", "ask about tissue samples". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:informationWithheld

fields.definition: Actions taken to make the shared data less specific or complete than in its original form. Suggests that alternative data of higher quality may be available on request.
fields.name: dataGeneralizations
fields.example: Example: "Coordinates generalized from original GPS coordinates to the nearest half degree grid cell". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:dataGeneralizations

fields.definition: A list of additional measurements, facts, characteristics, or assertions about the record. Meant to provide a mechanism for structured content.
fields.name: dynamicProperties
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to use a key:value encoding schema such as JSON. Examples: "{"heightInMeters":1.5}", "{"tragusLengthInMeters":0.014, "weightInGrams":120}", "{"natureOfID":"expert identification", "identificationEvidence":"cytochrome B sequence"}", "{"relativeHumidity":28, "airTemperatureInCelcius":22, "sampleSizeInKilograms":10}", "{"aspectHeading":277, "slopeInDegrees":6}", "{"iucnStatus":"vulnerable", "taxonDistribution":"Neuquén, Argentina"}". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:dynamicProperties

fields.definition: An identifier for the set of information associated with an Event (something that occurs at a place and time). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
fields.name: eventID
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:eventID

fields.definition: The name of, reference to, or description of the method or protocol used during an Event.
fields.name: samplingProtocol
fields.example: Examples: "UV light trap", "mist net", "bottom trawl", "ad hoc observation", "point count", "Penguins from space: faecal stains reveal the location of emperor penguin colonies, http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1466-8238.2009.00467.x", "Takats et al. 2001. Guidelines for Nocturnal Owl Monitoring in North America. Beaverhill Bird Observatory and Bird Studies Canada, Edmonton, Alberta. 32 pp.", "http://www.bsc-eoc.org/download/Owl.pdf". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:samplingProtocol

fields.definition: The amount of effort expended during an Event.
fields.name: samplingEffort
fields.example: Examples: "40 trap-nights", "10 observer-hours; 10 km by foot; 30 km by car". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:samplingEffort

fields.definition: The time or interval during which an Event occurred. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E).
fields.name: eventDate
fields.example: Examples: "14:07-0600" is 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, "08:40:21Z" is 8:40:21am UTC, "13:00:00Z/15:30:00Z" is the interval between 1pm UTC and 3:30pm UTC. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:eventTime

fields.definition: The earliest ordinal day of the year on which the Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.name: startDayOfYear
fields.example: Examples: "1" (=1 Jan), "366" (=31 Dec), "365" (=30 Dec in a leap year, 31 Dec in a non-leap year). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:startDayOfYear

fields.definition: The latest ordinal day of the year on which the Event occurred (1 for January 1, 365 for December 31, except in a leap year, in which case it is 366).
fields.name: endDayOfYear
fields.example: Examples: "1" (=1 Jan), "366" (=31 Dec), "365" (=30 Dec in a leap year, 31 Dec in a non-leap year). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:endDayOfYear

fields.definition: The four-digit year in which the Event occurred, according to the Common Era Calendar.
fields.name: year
fields.example: Example: "2008". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:year

fields.definition: The ordinal month in which the Event occurred.
fields.name: month
fields.example: Examples: "1" (=January), "10" (=October). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:month

fields.definition: The integer day of the month on which the Event occurred.
fields.name: day
fields.example: Examples: "9", "28". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:day

fields.definition: The verbatim original representation of the date and time information for an Event.
fields.name: verbatimEventDate
fields.example: Examples: "spring 1910", "Marzo 2002", "1999-03-XX", "17IV1934". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:verbatimEventDate

fields.definition: An identifier given to the event in the field. Often serves as a link between field notes and the Event.
fields.name: fieldNumber
fields.example: Example: "RV Sol 87-03-08". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:fieldNumber

fields.definition: One of a) an indicator of the existence of, b) a reference to (publication, URI), or c) the text of notes taken in the field about the Event.
fields.name: fieldNotes
fields.example: Example: "notes available in Grinnell-Miller Library". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:fieldNotes

fields.definition: Comments or notes about the Event.
fields.name: eventRemarks
fields.example: Example: "after the recent rains the river is nearly at flood stage". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:eventRemarks

fields.definition: A spatial region or named place.
fields.name: Location

fields.definition: An identifier for the geographic region within which the Location occurred. Recommended best practice is to use an persistent identifier from a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: higherGeographyID
fields.example: Example: "TGN: 1002002" for Prov. Tierra del Fuego, Argentina. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:higherGeographyID

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of geographic names less specific than the information captured in the locality term.
fields.name: higherGeography
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '), with terms in order from least specific to most specific. Examples: "North Atlantic Ocean", "South America | Argentina | Patagonia | Parque Nacional Nahuel Huapi | Neuquén | Los Lagos" with accompanying values "South America" in Continent, "Argentina" in Country, "Neuquén" in StateProvince, and "Los Lagos" in County. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:higherGeography

fields.definition: The name of the continent in which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: continent
fields.example: Examples: "Africa", "Antarctica", "Asia", "Europe", "North America", "Oceania", "South America". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:continent

fields.definition: The name of the water body in which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: waterBody
fields.example: Examples: "Indian Ocean", "Baltic Sea", "Hudson River". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:waterBody

fields.definition: The name of the island group in which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: islandGroup
fields.example: Examples: "Alexander Archipelago", "Seychelles". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:islandGroup

fields.definition: The name of the island on or near which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: island
fields.example: Examples: "Isla Victoria", "Vancouver", "Viti Levu", "Zanzibar". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:island

fields.definition: The name of the country or major administrative unit in which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names.
fields.name: country
fields.example: Examples: "Denmark", "Colombia", "España". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:country

fields.definition: The standard code for the country in which the Location occurs. Recommended best practice is to use ISO 3166-1-alpha-2 country codes.
fields.name: countryCode
fields.example: Examples: "AR" for Argentina, "SV" for El Salvador. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:countryCode

fields.definition: The name of the next smaller administrative region than country (state, province, canton, department, region, etc.) in which the Location occurs.
fields.name: stateProvince
fields.example: Examples: "Montana", "Minas Gerais", "Córdoba". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:stateProvince

fields.definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than stateProvince (county, shire, department, etc.) in which the Location occurs.
fields.name: county
fields.example: Examples: "Missoula", "Los Lagos", "Mataró". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:county

fields.definition: The full, unabbreviated name of the next smaller administrative region than county (city, municipality, etc.) in which the Location occurs. Do not use this term for a nearby named place that does not contain the actual location.
fields.name: municipality
fields.example: Examples: "Holzminden". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:municipality

fields.definition: The specific description of the place. Less specific geographic information can be provided in other geographic terms (higherGeography, continent, country, stateProvince, county, municipality, waterBody, island, islandGroup). This term may contain information modified from the original to correct perceived errors or standardize the description.
fields.name: locality
fields.example: Example: "Bariloche, 25 km NNE via Ruta Nacional 40 (=Ruta 237)". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:locality

fields.definition: The original textual description of the place.
fields.name: verbatimLocality
fields.example: Example: "25 km NNE Bariloche por R. Nac. 237". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:verbatimLocality

fields.definition: The geographic latitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are north of the Equator, negative values are south of it. Legal values lie between -90 and 90, inclusive.
fields.name: decimalLatitude
fields.example: Example: "-41.0983423". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:decimalLatitude

fields.definition: The geographic longitude (in decimal degrees, using the spatial reference system given in geodeticDatum) of the geographic center of a Location. Positive values are east of the Greenwich Meridian, negative values are west of it. Legal values lie between -180 and 180, inclusive.
fields.name: decimalLongitude
fields.example: Example: "-121.1761111". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:decimalLongitude

fields.definition: The ellipsoid, geodetic datum, or spatial reference system (SRS) upon which the geographic coordinates given in decimalLatitude and decimalLongitude as based. Recommended best practice is use the EPSG code as a controlled vocabulary to provide an SRS, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the geodetic datum, if known. Otherwise use a controlled vocabulary for the name or code of the ellipsoid, if known. If none of these is known, use the value "unknown".
fields.name: geodeticDatum
fields.example: Examples: "EPSG:4326", "WGS84", "NAD27", "Campo Inchauspe", "European 1950", "Clarke 1866". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:geodeticDatum

fields.definition: An identifier for the set of location information (data associated with dcterms:Location). May be a global unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set.
fields.name: locationID
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:locationID

fields.definition: The full name of the lithostratigraphic formation from which the cataloged item was collected.
fields.name: formation
fields.example: Examples: "Notch Peak Fromation", "House Limestone", "Fillmore Formation". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:formation

fields.definition: The full name of the lithostratigraphic member from which the cataloged item was collected.
fields.name: member
fields.example: Examples: "Lava Dam Member", "Hellnmaria Member". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:member

fields.definition: Geological information, such as stratigraphy, that qualifies a region or place.
fields.name: GeologicalContext
fields.example: Example: A lithostratigraphic layer. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:GeologicalContext

fields.definition: The full name of the lithostratigraphic group from which the cataloged item was collected.
fields.name: group
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:group

fields.name: bed
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:bed

fields.definition: A relationship of one rdfs:Resource (http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#Resource) to another.
fields.name: ResourceRelationship
fields.example: Resources can be thought of as identifiable records or instances of classes and may include, but need not be limited to Occurrences, Organisms, MaterialSamples, Events, Locations, GeologicalContexts, Identifications, or Taxa. Example: An instance of an Organism is the mother of another instance of an Organism. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:ResourceRelationship

fields.definition: A measurement of or fact about an rdfs:Resource (http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#Resource).
fields.name: MeasurementOrFact
fields.example: Resources can be thought of as identifiable records or instances of classes and may include, but need not be limited to Occurrences, Organisms, MaterialSamples, Events, Locations, GeologicalContexts, Identifications, or Taxa. Examples: The weight of an organism in grams. The number of placental scars. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:MeasurementOrFact

fields.definition: The number of individuals represented present at the time of the Occurrence.
fields.name: individualCount
fields.example: Examples: "1", "25". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:individualCount

fields.definition: The sex of the biological individual(s) represented in the Occurrence. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: sex
fields.example: Examples: "female", "hermaphrodite", "8 males, 4 females". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:sex

fields.definition: The age class or life stage of the biological individual(s) at the time the Occurrence was recorded. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: lifeStage
fields.example: Examples: "egg", "eft", "juvenile", "adult", "2 adults 4 juveniles". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:lifeStage

fields.definition: The reproductive condition of the biological individual(s) represented in the Occurrence. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: reproductiveCondition
fields.example: Examples" "non-reproductive", "pregnant", "in bloom", "fruit-bearing". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:reproductiveCondition

fields.definition: A description of the behavior shown by the subject at the time the Occurrence was recorded. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: behavior
fields.example: Examples: "roosting", "foraging", "running". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:behavior

fields.definition: The process by which the biological individual(s) represented in the Occurrence became established at the location. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: establishmentMeans
fields.example: Examples: "native", "introduced", "naturalised", "invasive", "managed". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:establishmentMeans

fields.definition: A statement about the presence or absence of a Taxon at a Location. Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary.
fields.name: occurrenceStatus
fields.example: Examples: "present", "absent". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:occurrenceStatus

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of preparations and preservation methods for a specimen.
fields.name: preparations
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "fossil", "cast", "photograph", "DNA extract", "skin | "skull | skeleton", "whole animal (ETOH) | tissue (EDTA)". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:preparations

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of previous or alternate fully qualified catalog numbers or other human-used identifiers for the same Occurrence, whether in the current or any other data set or collection.
fields.name: otherCatalogNumbers
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "FMNH:Mammal:1234", "NPS YELLO6778 | MBG 33424". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:otherCatalogNumbers

fields.name: associatedMedia
fields.example: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, global unique identifier, URI) of media associated with the Occurrence.

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, bibliographic reference, global unique identifier, URI) of literature associated with the Occurrence.
fields.name: associatedReferences
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/abstract/322/5899/261", "Christopher J. Conroy, Jennifer L. Neuwald. 2008. Phylogeographic study of the California vole, Microtus californicus Journal of Mammalogy, 89(3):755-767.", "Steven R. Hoofer and Ronald A. Van Den Bussche. 2001. Phylogenetic Relationships of Plecotine Bats and Allies Based on Mitochondrial Ribosomal Sequences. Journal of Mammalogy 82(1):131-137. | Walker, Faith M., Jeffrey T. Foster, Kevin P. Drees, Carol L. Chambers. 2014. Spotted bat (Euderma maculatum) microsatellite discovery using illumina sequencing. Conservation Genetics Resources.". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:associatedReferences

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers (publication, global unique identifier, URI) of genetic sequence information associated with the Occurrence.
fields.name: associatedSequences
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/U34853.1", "http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/GU328060 | http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/AF326093". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:associatedSequences

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of identifiers or names of taxa and their associations with the Occurrence.
fields.name: associatedTaxa
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '), and to separate the relationship from the taxon with a colon (':'). Examples: "host: Quercus alba", "parasitoid of:Cyclocephala signaticollis | predator of Apis mellifera". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:associatedTaxa

fields.definition: A taxonomic determination (e.g., the assignment to a taxon).
fields.name: Identification
fields.example: Example: A subspecies determination of an organism. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:Identification

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of names of people, groups, or organizations who assigned the Taxon to the subject.
fields.name: identifiedBy
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "James L. Patton", "Theodore Pappenfuss | Robert Macey". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:identifiedBy

fields.definition: The date on which the subject was identified as representing the Taxon. Recommended best practice is to use an encoding scheme, such as ISO 8601:2004(E).
fields.name: dateIdentified
fields.example: Examples: "1963-03-08T14:07-0600" is 8 Mar 1963 2:07pm in the time zone six hours earlier than UTC, "2009-02-20T08:40Z" is 20 Feb 2009 8:40am UTC, "1809-02-12" is 12 Feb 1809, "1906-06" is Jun 1906, "1971" is just that year, "2007-03-01T13:00:00Z/2008-05-11T15:30:00Z" is the interval between 1 Mar 2007 1pm UTC and 11 May 2008 3:30pm UTC, "2007-11-13/15" is the interval between 13 Nov 2007 and 15 Nov 2007. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:dateIdentified

fields.definition: Comments or notes about the Identification.
fields.name: identificationRemarks
fields.example: Example: "Distinguished between Anthus correndera and Anthus hellmayri based on the comparative lengths of the uñas.". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:identificationRemarks

fields.definition: A brief phrase or a standard term ("cf.", "aff.") to express the determiner's doubts about the Identification.
fields.name: identificationQualifier
fields.example: Examples: 1) For the determination "Quercus aff. agrifolia var. oxyadenia", identificationQualifier would be "aff. agrifolia var. oxyadenia" with accompanying values "Quercus" in genus, "agrifolia" in specificEpithet, "oxyadenia" in infraspecificEpithet, and "var." in rank. 2) For the determination "Quercus agrifolia cf. var. oxyadenia", identificationQualifier would be "cf. var. oxyadenia " with accompanying values "Quercus" in genus, "agrifolia" in specificEpithet, "oxyadenia" in infraspecificEpithet, and "var." in rank. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:identificationQualifier

fields.definition: A list (concatenated and separated) of nomenclatural types (type status, typified scientific name, publication) applied to the subject.
fields.name: typeStatus
fields.example: The recommended best practice is to separate the values with a vertical bar (' | '). Examples: "holotype of Ctenomys sociabilis. Pearson O. P., and M. I. Christie. 1985. Historia Natural, 5(37):388", "holotype of Pinus abies | holotype of Picea abies". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:typeStatus

fields.definition: A group of organisms (sensu http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0100026) considered by taxonomists to form a homogeneous unit.
fields.name: Taxon
fields.example: Example: The genus Truncorotaloides as published by Brönnimann et al. in 1953 in the Journal of Paleontology Vol. 27(6) p. 817-820. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:Taxon

fields.definition: The full scientific name, with authorship and date information if known. When forming part of an Identification, this should be the name in lowest level taxonomic rank that can be determined. This term should not contain identification qualifications, which should instead be supplied in the identificationQualifier term.
fields.name: scientificName
fields.example: Examples: "Coleoptera" (order), "Vespertilionidae" (family), "Manis" (genus), "Ctenomys sociabilis" (genus + specificEpithet), "Ambystoma tigrinum diaboli" (genus + specificEpithet + infraspecificEpithet), "Roptrocerus typographi (Györfi, 1952)" (genus + specificEpithet + scientificNameAuthorship), "Quercus agrifolia var. oxyadenia (Torr.) J.T. Howell" (genus + specificEpithet + taxonRank + infraspecificEpithet + scientificNameAuthorship). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:scientificName

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the kingdom in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: kingdom
fields.example: Examples: "Animalia", "Plantae". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:kingdom

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the phylum or division in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: phylum
fields.example: Examples: "Chordata" (phylum), "Bryophyta" (division). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:phylum

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the class in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: class
fields.example: Examples: "Mammalia", "Hepaticopsida". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:class

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the order in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: order
fields.example: Examples: "Carnivora", "Monocleales". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:order

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the family in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: family
fields.example: Examples: "Felidae", "Monocleaceae". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:family

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the genus in which the taxon is classified.
fields.name: genus
fields.example: Examples: "Puma", "Monoclea". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:genus

fields.definition: The name of the first or species epithet of the scientificName.
fields.name: specificEpithet
fields.example: Examples: "concolor", "gottschei". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:specificEpithet

fields.definition: A point or period of time associated with an event in the lifecycle of the resource.
fields.name: date

fields.definition: The full scientific name of the tribe in which the taxon is classified
fields.name: tribe
fields.example: Examples: "Alcelaphini", "Hominini"

fields.definition: A unique integer identification number for each database item including observations about fossils that are not collected. This term serves as an internal unique identifier and primary key within the database. This field is synonymous with DwC:catalogNumber.
fields.name: catalogNumberNumeric

fields.definition: A unique nine-digit integer identifier for each item that is collected. Printed linear barcodes accompany each fossil specimen in the collection.
fields.name: barcode

fields.definition: DwC:institutionCode. All DRP specimens belong to the National Museum of Ethiopia and the institutional code ascribed to this museum is NME.
fields.name: DwC:institutionCode
fields.example: "NME"

fields.definition: The date that a record was last modified in the database. Synonymous with Dc:modified
fields.name: dateLastModified

fields.definition: Integer values designating a paleontological locality
fields.name: paleoLocalityNumber

fields.definition: The integer identifier of the item collected at a given locality.
fields.name: itemNumber

fields.definition: Alpha numeric designation of item subparts.
fields.name: itemPart

fields.definition: An identifier (preferably unique) for the record within the data set or collection.
fields.name: catalogNumber
fields.example: Examples: "2008.1334", "145732a", "145732". For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:catalogNumber

fields.definition: The formal scientific name of the item. For biological entities this is the most specific taxonomic assignment (e.g. species). For other entities the scientific name follows the domain specific taxonomy.
fields.name: itemScientificName
fields.example: "Australopithecus afarensis", "pmag", "Flake"

fields.definition: A brief description of the item.
fields.name: itemDescription
fields.example: "astragalus", "paleomag sample"

fields.name: verbatimCoordinateSystem
fields.example: "decimal degrees", "degrees decimal minutes", "degrees minutes seconds", "UTM"

fields.name: DwC:georeferenceRemarks
fields.example: "assumed distance by road (Hwy. 101)"

fields.definition:
The collection method and protocols used during field campaigns. The field uses a controlled vocabulary:
surface standard
surface prospecting
surface intensive
surface prospecting while moving close to the ground in a crouch or crawl
surface complete
surface prospecting where all observed fossils are collected
exploratory survey
rapid surface prospecting where only some fossils are collected
dry screening 5mm
fossils recovered by sieving sediment through 5 mm screens
dry screening 2mm
fossils recovered by sieving sediment through 2 mm screens
wet screening 1mm
fossils recovered by wet sieving sediment through 1mm screens
This terms is synonymous with DwC:samplingProtocol
fields.name: collectionMethod
fields.example: "surface", "surface2", "wet screen 1mm", "UV light trap", "mist net", "bottom trawl", "ad hoc observation", "point count", "Penguins from space: faecal stains reveal the location of emperor penguin colonies, http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1466-8238.2009.00467.x", "Takats et al. 2001. Guidelines for Nocturnal Owl Monitoring in North America. Beaverhill Bird Observatory and Bird Studies Canada, Edmonton, Alberta. 32 pp.", "http://www.bsc-eoc.org/download/Owl.pdf"

fields.definition: The person who recorded the item. For the drp database this term uses a controlled vocabulary, the names of team members authorized to do data collection. This term is synonymous with DwC: recordedBy
fields.name: collector
fields.example: "Denis Geraads"

fields.definition: The person who found or discovered the item. This term is distinct from "collector" which refers to the person who recorded the item.
fields.name: finder
fields.example: "Team", "Rene Bobe"

fields.definition: The physical storage location of an item. All items collected by the drp are stored in the National Museum of Ethiopia (NME) in numbered drawers.
fields.name: disposition
fields.example: "NME drawer 14"

fields.definition: Optional, additional remarks about the collection event
fields.name: collectionRemarks
fields.example: "two associated fragments"

fields.name: monthCollected
fields.example: "January"

fields.definition: For the drp this field indicates the number of elements contained in the item. Typically every item refers to a single thing, but this field can be used to document the count of elements in a bulk collection. This is slightly different from the exact use of individualCount
fields.name: DwC:individualCount
preparationsStatus
fields.example: "needs prep"

fields.definition: The name of the upper stratigraphic marker bed used as a stratigraphic reference.
fields.name: stratigraphicMarkerUpper
fields.example: "SHT", "InaalaleTuff"

fields.definition: An integer indicating the stratigraphic position of the fossil when it was found. This field does not denote the stratigraphic level from which the item came if it was ex situ. The value indicates the distance in meters above or below the stratigraphic marker identified in the field "stratigraphicMarkerUpper". Positive values indicate distances above the marker bed and negative values indicate distances below the marker bed.
fields.name: distanceFromUpper

fields.definition: The name of the upper stratigraphic marker bed used as a stratigraphic reference.
fields.name: stratigraphicMarkerLower
fields.example: "SHT"

fields.definition: An integer indicating the stratigraphic position of the fossil when it was found. This field does not denote the stratigraphic level from which the item came if it was ex situ. The value indicates the distance in meters above or below the stratigraphic marker identified in the field "stratigraphicMarkerLower". Positive values indicate distances above the marker bed and negative values indicate distances below the marker bed.
fields.name: distanceFromLower

fields.definition: The stratigraphic analytical unit to which the item belongs. This might be a member, formation or any other stratigraphic range.
fields.name: analyticalUnit
fields.example: "Basal Member'

fields.definition: Whether the item was found in its presumed original geological context (Yes), or whether it is has clearly been relocated from its original geological context (No).
fields.name: inSitu

fields.definition: Foreign key to the locality databset
fields.name: localityId

fields.definition: Bourdian flake type.  The typological characterization of each flake type, with reference to the canonical reference bourdes et al.  This should always be emntered and referenced.
fields.name: Flake Type

fields.definition: Date that the artifact was collected
fields.name: Date Collected

fields.definition: The length of the object, always measured.
fields.name: length

fields.definition: Mustache lo-fi elit disrupt placeat fap. Velit chambray polaroid, Odd Future PBR authentic assumenda id Banksy ennui elit eiusmod pop-up. Kale chips Cosby sweater salvia, VHS fashion axe nulla whatever. Etsy artisan iPhone ad, kogi Neutra bespoke forage. Sapiente chia post-ironic, typewriter High Life tote bag butcher occupy. Placeat officia sed Brooklyn. Truffaut selfies Schlitz gentrify.
fields.name: test6

fields.definition: The size or duration of the resource.
fields.name: extent

fields.definition: A resource that acts or has the power to act.
fields.name: Agent
AgentClass
fields.example: Examples of Agent Class include groups seen as classes, such as students, women, charities, lecturers.

fields.definition: A book, article, or other documentary resource.
fields.name: BibliographicResource

fields.definition: An interval of time that is named or defined by its start and end dates.
fields.name: PeriodOfTime
Event
fields.example: Metadata for an event provides descriptive information that is the basis for discovery of the purpose, location, duration, and responsible agents associated with an event. Examples include an exhibition, webcast, conference, workshop, open day, performance, battle, trial, wedding, tea party, conflagration.

fields.definition: A visual representation other than text.
fields.name: Image
fields.example: Examples include images and photographs of physical objects, paintings, prints, drawings, other images and graphics, animations and moving pictures, film, diagrams, maps, musical notation. Note that Image may include both electronic and physical representations.

fields.name: FileFormat
fields.example: Examples include the formats defined by the list of Internet Media Types.

fields.definition: An existence of an Organism (sensu http://rs.tdwg.org/dwc/terms/Organism) at a particular place at a particular time.
fields.name: Occurrence
fields.example: Examples: A wolf pack on the shore of Kluane Lake in 1988. A virus in a plant leaf in a the New York Botanical Garden at 15:29 on 2014-10-23. A fungus in Central Park in the summer of 1929. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:Occurrence

fields.definition: A preserved specimen that is a fossil.
fields.name: FossilSpecimen
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:FossilSpecimen

fields.definition: A particular organism or defined group of organisms considered to be taxonomically homogeneous.
fields.name: Organism
LivingSpecimen
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:LivingSpecimen

fields.definition: A specimen that has been preserved.
fields.name: PreservedSpecimen

fields.definition: An action that occurs at some location during some time.
fields.name: Event

fields.definition: An output of a human observation process.
fields.name: Human Observation
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:HumanObservation

fields.definition: An output of a machine observation process.
fields.name: Machine Observation
fields.example: For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:MachineObservation

fields.definition: An inanimate, three-dimensional object or substance.
fields.name: PhysicalObject
fields.example: Note that digital representations of, or surrogates for, these objects should use Image, Text or one of the other types.

fields.name: organismQuantity
fields.example: An organismQuantity must have a corresponding organismQuantityType, e.g., "27" for organismQuantity with "individuals" for organismQuantityType; "12.5" for organismQuantity with "%biomass" for organismQuantityType; "r" for organismQuantity with "BraunBlanquetScale" for organismQuantityType. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:organismQuantity

fields.definition: The type of quantification system used for the quantity of organisms.
fields.name: organismQuantityType
fields.example: An organismQuantityType must have a corresponding organismQuantity, e.g., "27" for organismQuantity with "individuals" for organismQuantityType; "12.5" for organismQuantity with "%biomass" for organismQuantityType; "r" for organismQuantity with "BraunBlanquetScale" for organismQuantityType. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:organismQuantityType

fields.definition: An identifier for the broader Event that groups this and potentially other Events.
fields.name: parentEventID
fields.example: May be a globally unique identifier or an identifier specific to the data set. Example: "A1" as parentEventID to identify the main Whittaker Plot in nested samples, each with its own eventID (e.g., "A1:1", "A1:2"). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:parentEventID

fields.definition: A numeric value for a measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling event.
fields.name: sampleSizeValue
fields.example: A sampleSizeValue must have a corresponding sampleSizeUnit. Example: "5" for sampleSizeValue with "metre" for sampleSizeUnit. For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:sampleSizeValue

fields.definition: The unit of measurement of the size (time duration, length, area, or volume) of a sample in a sampling event.
fields.name: sampleSizeUnit
fields.example: A sampleSizeUnit must have a corresponding sampleSizeValue, e.g., "5" for sampleSizeValue with "metre" for sampleSizeUnit. Examples: "minute", "hour", "day", "metre", "square metre", "cubic metre". Recommended best practice is to use a controlled vocabulary such as the Ontology of Units of Measure http://www.wurvoc.org/vocabularies/om-1.8/ of SI units, derived units, or other non-SI units accepted for use within the SI (e.g., minute, hour, day, litre). For discussion see http://terms.tdwg.org/wiki/dwc:sampleSizeUnit
